body: The error could be due to a path issue or (more likely) due to the complexity of the geometry in your model. I was able to make it work by changing "Parede" to a mesh instead of Brep and then using MSH2RAD. See attached. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/LuvHCR6YrSJiTF75nCjifgtEektJ-1yrHPrqCBdYGFeFTH2UrCCwYuTj21-ai2OtuYEl1tsY9HjAUdjMVfcW6Ks7WyKQF3tj/Simulation.png) This is the change that I made to your simulation. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/LuvHCR6YrSKYMaQ9o1xHOgpdOy6OrYhxzsR4UQTYPuwUtLeIYkSGelQxWtBlSvhocCycSHh9pG4Ha81J67TXKyIRc9skOXoq/Mesh2Rad.png) It's usually not a good idea to have space in the path, as you do for "Projeto de Pesquisa", when dealing with Radiance. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/LuvHCR6YrSIAq6XSWTw*3BuwC3A4P85fVuIN0LB*l6huBr4xmHJCZpCmpZsCBcEnfAoJMfWDaIRqh3Fb*ZJfZtx5tLQ9oTgY/PathIssue.png) cc: Mostapha/Chris. The culprit is the octree resolution setting of 2048. I guess most users won't run into issues with that kind of setting. So, I am not sure if a fix is needed for this at all. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/LuvHCR6YrSKiPttD8UEkgXOfg2QpyVgda0ZtEA652R8YsSjiSrVjZG4Vttq832DGmtjMq-KYU10lsKccJfIe9FoMHFS587LP/OctreeError.png)
